issue.title: §[formatter.requirements]: Formatter requirements forbid use of fc.arg()

discussion.p: The requirements on the expression f.format(t, fc) in [tab:formatter] say

blockquote.p: Formats t according to the specifiers stored in *this, writes the output to fc.out() and returns an iterator past the end of the output range. The output shall only depend on t, fc.locale(), and the range [pc.begin(), pc.end()) from the last call to f.parse(pc).

discussion.p: Strictly speaking, this wording effectively forbids f.format(t, fc) from calling fc.arg(n), whose motivation is precisely to allow a formatter to rely on arguments different from t. According to this interpretation, there's no conforming way to implement the "{ arg-id }" form of the width and precision fields of standard format specifiers. Moreover, the formatter described in the example if paragraph /8 would also be non-conforming.
Set priority to 3 after reflector discussions.

blockquote.p: This wording is relative to N4861.

tr.td: Formats t according to the specifiers stored in *this, writes the output to fc.out() and returns an iterator past the end of the output range. The output shall only depend on t, fc.locale(), and the range [pc.begin(), pc.end()) from the last call to f.parse(pc), and fc.arg(n), where n is a size_t index value that has been validated with a call to pc.check_arg_id(n) in the last call to f.parse(pc).

discussion.p: During reflector discussion Victor said that the formatter requirements should allow dependency on any of the format arguments in the context. The wording below reflects that.
Set status to Tentatively Ready after six votes in favour during reflector poll.

resolution.p: This wording is relative to N4885.

tr.td: Formats t according to the specifiers stored in *this, writes the output to fc.out() and returns an iterator past the end of the output range. The output shall only depend on t, fc.locale(), fc.arg(n) for any value n of type size_t, and the range [pc.begin(), pc.end()) from the last call to f.parse(pc).
